thread.title: Fed's Lacker restates rate hike case
thread.title_full: Fed's Lacker restates rate hike case | Business Spectator

author: Dow Jones newswires
title: Fed's Lacker restates rate hike case
text:
Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond's President Jeffrey Lacker has said that he believes the case for higher short-term interest rates remains as strong now as it did when he opposed his colleagues' decision to keep rates unchanged at rock-bottom levels last month.
Speaking on Fox Business Network , Mr Lacker shrugged off recent economic data showing a weaker turn for the US economy's performance and pointed to continued strength in consumer spending as a reason to be optimistic about the outlook.
"The higher sustained growth we've seen in real consumer spending strongly suggests that real interest rates need to be higher than they are now," Mr Lacker said. "It seems unlikely" the current level of short-term rates "is going to be sustainable with this stretch of consumer spending growth."
But the monetary official declined to say what he thinks Fed officials should do with monetary policy when they meet at the end of this month, even as he implied he's likely to argue again for a boost in borrowing costs.
"I don't know whether we're going to raise rates in October or not...I'll make a final decision on the way in, but my views haven't changed much since September," the official said.
Mr Lacker added in a separate internet video with the channel that he deems the risk of raising rates now as minimal, adding "breaking the ice" on moving rates up is important. He described a rate rise by year's end as plausible.
Mr Lacker's interview with the television channel came as the outlook for US central bank policy has fallen into flux. Officials held off on raising key rates off the current near-zero level at their mid-September meeting in a bid to take stock of how worrisome international events might affect an otherwise healthy US economic outlook.
Mr Lacker dissented against the decision of his colleagues then and said the time had arrived to raise rates. Since that gathering, a number of Fed officials have continued to argue in favour of raising rates this year, but most agree that path is contingent on how the economy performs.
Given the Fed's current concerns, most observers are looking to its December policy meeting as a potential time to act, with the coming October gathering unlikely to result in a change in rates.
But even as regional Fed bank bosses have been arguing in favour of rate increases, several Washington-based governors have muddied the waters considerably over recent days.
In a speech on Monday, Lael Brainard said uncertainties over the outlook due to global events are making it harder to know when rates might go up. On Tuesday, Daniel Tarullo said in a CNBC interview that "right now my expectation is, given where I think the economy would go, I wouldn't expect it would be appropriate to raise rates" this year.
The caution shown by Fed governors, especially Mr Tarullo, is particularly notable for the fact that these officials usually move in lockstep with the central bank's leader.
Fed chair Janet Yellen said late last month she still expected to boost rates this year, so central bank watchers are trying to glean from the shifting views of the two governors a sign of whether Ms Yellen is also now less supportive of a 2015 rate boost.
Regional bank officials such as Mr Lacker believe the US economy has essentially met the Fed's goals for hiring and inflation, citing a jobless rate that is largely at the level where they expect it to stand in the longer run.
While the Fed has fallen short of hitting its 2 per cent price target for more than three years and officials don't expect it to hit that level until 2018, a number of Fed officials blame weak price gains on temporary factors and are confident inflation will return to desired levels over time.
Mr Lacker said in the TV interview that he was confident the inflation rate would increase back to target over time. He also said an ebbing in the rate of hiring may have a very positive message, explaining "it's unlikely there's any meaningful slack left in the labor market, and it's quite plausible the slowdown in the labour market reflects the increasing difficulty some firms are facing in finding qualified workers."
